name: ardea-alba
definition: The great egrets are white herons of the genera Ardea, characteristically having long, showy plumes during the breeding season.
description:
The great egret is a large, widely distributed egret, with four subspecies found in Asia, Africa, the Americas, and southern Europe.

It has a slow flight, with its neck retracted. This is characteristic of herons and bitterns, and distinguishes them from storks, cranes, ibises, and spoonbills, which extend their necks in flight.

The great egret is partially migratory, with northern hemisphere birds moving south from areas with colder winters.

The great egret is a large heron with all-white plumage.

Standing up to one meter tall, this species can measure 80 to 104 centimeters in length and have a wingspan of 131 to 170 centimeters.

Body mass can range from 680 to 1,500 grams. It is thus only slightly smaller than the great blue or grey heron.

Apart from size, the great egret can be distinguished from other white egrets by its yellow bill and black legs and feet.

In breeding plumage, delicate ornamental feathers are borne on the back.

Males and females are identical in appearance; juveniles look like nonbreeding adults.

The great egret is generally a very successful species with a large and expanding range, occurring worldwide in temperate and tropical habitats.

Great egrets are found near water, salt or fresh, and feed in wetlands, streams, ponds, tidal flats, and other areas.

The great egret forages in shallow water or drier habitats.

It feeds mainly on fish, frogs, small mammals, and occasionally small reptiles and insects.

Most of the time, the great egret stands still, allowing the prey to come within its striking distance of its bill, which it uses as a spear.

It often waits motionless for prey, or slowly stalks its victim.

The species breeds in colonies in trees close to large lakes with reed beds or other extensive wetlands, preferably at height of 3 to 12.2 meters.

It begins to breed at 2 to 3 years of age by forming monogamous pairs each season.

If the pairing carries over to the next season is not known.

The male selects the nest area, starts a nest, and then attracts a female.

The nest, made of sticks and lined with plant material, could be up to 92 centimeters across.

Up to six bluish green eggs are laid at one time.

Both sexes incubate the eggs and the incubation period is 23 to 26 days.

The young are fed by regurgitation by both parents and they are able to fly within 6 to 7 weeks.

facts.name: Communicate via several calls
facts.value: Great egrets communicate via several calls. High-pitched, squeaky calls can be heard during the breeding season. Threatened birds produce hoarse croaks.

facts.name: Diet is based on fish
facts.value: Diet of great egret is based on fish, frogs, snakes, crustaceans and insects that live in or near the water and lizards, small mammals and birds on the solid ground.

facts.name: Hunt solitary or in small flocks
facts.value: Great egret hunts solitary or gathered in small flocks.

facts.name: Occasionally steals food
facts.value: Great egret occasionally steals food from other birds and uses crocodiles' back as a "floating device".

facts.name: Covered with white plumage
facts.value: Great egret is covered with white plumage. It has long, yellow bill with black tip and long, black legs and feet.

facts.name: Can reach 1.04 meters in length
facts.value: Great egret can reach 94 to 104 centimeters in length, one meter in height and 680 to 1500 grams of weight.

facts.name: Wingspan of 1.46 meters
facts.value: Great egret has wingspan of 1.31 to 1.46 meters. It produces 2 wing beats per second and flies at the speed of 40 kilometers per hour. Neck is S-shaped during the flight.

facts.name: Natural enemies
facts.value: Natural enemies of great egrets are raccoons, owls and hawks. They attack young birds in the nest.

facts.name: Can survive 15 years in the wild
facts.value: Great egret can survive 15 years in the wild and 22 years in the captivity.

facts.name: Long, ornamental plumes
facts.value: Great egrets develop long, ornamental plumes on the back during the breeding season and spread them (in a fan-shaped manner) like peacocks during the courtship.

facts.name: Wait motionless for the prey
facts.value: Great egret stands motionless in the water and waits for the prey to come close enough. It catches the prey using the long, sharp bill in a fraction of a second.

facts.name: Mating season on spring
facts.value: Mating season of great egrets takes place during the spring and summer in temperate regions or throughout the year in tropical areas. Great egrets produce one brood per year.

facts.name: Mostly active at dusk and dawn
facts.value: Great egret is mostly active at dusk and dawn (crepuscular bird).

facts.name: Nest alone or in large colonies
facts.value: Great egrets nest alone or in colonies of up to 1,000 pairs of birds. Male starts to build nests using the long sticks and twigs, and female completes it. Nest is usually located in the trees or bushes near the water.

facts.name: Female lays 4 to 6 eggs
facts.value: Female lays 4 to 6 eggs that hatch after 23 to 27 days. Stronger chicks often kill the weakest birds in the nest to ensure enough food for themselves. Young great egrets are ready to leave the nest at the age of 21 to 25 days.

related.definition: The great blue heron is a large wading bird in the heron family Ardeidae, common near the shores of open water and in weatlands.
The great white pelican also known as the eastern white pelican, rosy pelican or white pelican is a bird in the pelican family.
The Eurasian spoonbill is a wading bird of the ibis and spoonbill family Threskiornithidae.
The Australian white ibis is a wading bird of the ibis family. It is widespread across much of Australia.
